textSections.title: Pre-Deployment Checklist
textSections.content:
Before you deploy, make sure:

**Code Quality:**
- [ ] No console.log() or debug code left in
- [ ] All features work in production mode (`npm run build && npm start`)
- [ ] No hard-coded secrets (API keys, passwords) in the code
- [ ] README.md is updated with project description

**Environment Setup:**
- [ ] All environment variables documented in .env.example
- [ ] Database (if any) is accessible from the internet
- [ ] API routes (if any) are tested

**User Experience:**
- [ ] Loading states exist for slow operations
- [ ] Error messages are user-friendly
- [ ] Mobile layout is tested (responsive design)
- [ ] Favicon and meta tags are set

**Legal/Admin:**
- [ ] Privacy policy (if collecting any data)
- [ ] Contact info / support email
- [ ] Analytics opt-in (if required by GDPR)

You don't need 100% here â€” 80% is good enough to ship.

textSections.title: Vercel Deployment Step-by-Step
textSections.content:
**1. Push your code to GitHub**
```bash
git add .
git commit -m 'Ready for deployment'
git push origin main
```

**2. Sign up for Vercel**
- Go to vercel.com
- Sign up with GitHub (easiest)
- Authorize Vercel to access your repos

**3. Import your project**
- Click 'New Project'
- Select your GitHub repo
- Vercel auto-detects Next.js settings
- Click 'Deploy'

**4. Set environment variables (if needed)**
- Go to Project Settings â†’ Environment Variables
- Add each variable from your .env.local
- Redeploy after adding variables

**5. Get your URL**
- Vercel gives you: your-project.vercel.app
- Visit it and test!

**6. Every future push auto-deploys**
- Push to `main` â†’ production
- Push to other branches â†’ preview deployments

textSections.title: Custom Domain Setup (Namecheap Example)
textSections.content:
**1. Buy your domain**
- Go to Namecheap.com (or Cloudflare, Google Domains)
- Search for your desired name
- Purchase (.com, .dev, .ai all work)

**2. In Vercel:**
- Go to Project Settings â†’ Domains
- Add your domain (e.g., myproject.com)
- Vercel shows you DNS records to add

**3. In Namecheap:**
- Go to Domain List â†’ Manage â†’ Advanced DNS
- Add these records (from Vercel):
  - A Record: @ â†’ 76.76.21.21
  - CNAME: www â†’ cname.vercel-dns.com
- Save changes

**4. Wait for DNS propagation**
- Usually 5-30 minutes
- Check status in Vercel dashboard
- When green checkmark appears, you're live!

**5. Set primary domain**
- In Vercel, set myproject.com as primary
- www.myproject.com will redirect automatically

textSections.title: Post-Launch Monitoring
textSections.content:
**Set up Vercel Analytics (free):**
- Enable in Project Settings â†’ Analytics
- See: page views, unique visitors, top pages
- No code changes needed

**Add Google Analytics (optional but recommended):**
- Create GA4 property
- Add tracking code to your Next.js app
- See: user behavior, demographics, conversion funnels

**Monitor errors:**
- Check Vercel deployment logs daily
- Set up error tracking (Sentry is free tier)
- Fix critical bugs within 24 hours

**Respond to users:**
- Set up a contact form or support email
- Reply to all feedback in the first week
- Thank people for bug reports!

**Weekly check-in:**
- Traffic trends (growing or flat?)
- Common error messages
- User feedback themes
- Plan next iteration

textSections.title: Key Definitions
textSections.content:
**Deployment:** The process of making your app accessible on the internet

**Domain:** A human-readable web address (e.g., google.com)

**DNS (Domain Name System):** Translates domain names to server IP addresses

**SSL/TLS Certificate:** Enables HTTPS (secure connection) â€” Vercel provides this automatically

**Environment Variable:** Configuration values (API keys, DB URLs) kept separate from code

**Analytics:** Tools that track how users interact with your site

**Production:** The live version of your app that real users access

commonMistakes.mistake: Deploying with secrets in the code
commonMistakes.explanation: Use environment variables! Never commit API keys to GitHub.

commonMistakes.mistake: Not testing the production build locally first
commonMistakes.explanation: Run `npm run build && npm start` locally before deploying to catch build errors.
Ship with what works, iterate based on real user feedback.
You can't improve what you don't measure. At minimum, enable Vercel Analytics.
Share multiple times in different places. Not everyone sees your first post.

reflectionQuestions: What feels scarier: building your project or sharing it with the world? Why?
Who's the first person you want to show your deployed project to?
What would make you proud of this project a year from now?
